title: Former White House Official to Avoid Congressional Testimony for Now
summary: House panel has agreed to submit written questions to Don McGahn's ex-chief of staff. A former senior White House official cited frequently in Special Counsel Robert Mueller's report has reached agreement with Democratic lawmakers to avoid testifying before Congress for now, her lawyer said. The pact temporarily defuses another point of tension between House Democrats and the White House.

title: Trump Plans 'Major' Iran Sanctions
summary: President also said retaliatory strike on country was scrapped to avoid unnecessary Iranian casualties. WASHINGTON-President Trump tweeted that he plans to impose "major additional Sanctions on Iran on Monday," following his decision to call off a military attack on the country.

title: New Hampshire Motorcycle Crash Kills Seven
summary: Accident involved motorcycle club in New England that includes Marines and their spouses. RANDOLPH, N.H.-Motorcyclists from a club whose members include former U.S. Marines collided with a pickup truck on a rural highway on Friday, killing seven.

title: Trump Middle East Peace Plan Calls for $50 Billion in Investment
summary: The blueprint makes no mention of some of the most difficult issues of the conflict; 'Let's let people study it, give feedback.'. TEL AVIV-The Trump administration's Middle East peace plan would marshal $50 billion in investments over 10 years for the Palestinian territories and neighbors Jordan, Egypt and Lebanon, administration officials said Saturday.

title: U.N. Rights Official Takes Pulse of Venezuela Ahead of Key Report
summary: Michelle Bachelet's findings could help heighten international pressure on the increasingly isolated regime. CARACAS, Venezuela-The United Nations top human-rights official, on her first visit to Venezuela, said she urged President Nicolás Maduro's authoritarian government to release political prisoners and cease torture but also warned that international sanctions could aggravate a dire humanitarian crisis.

title: Stonewall Wasn't the Start of the Gay Rights Struggle
summary: In the mid-1960s, activist Frank Kameny led a campaign for equality that was rooted in American ideals.. Next weekend marks the 50th anniversary of the Stonewall uprising, when thousands of people poured into the streets of Greenwich Village in New York City to protest a police raid on a gay bar. State harassment of gay people had been commonplace for decades, but that night, the patrons at the Stonewall Inn had had enough-and finally decided to fight back.

title: David Plastow Steered Rolls-Royce to a Renaissance
summary: Under his leadership, the company emerged from bankruptcy and launched celebrated models: the Corniche, Camargue and Silver Spirit.

title: Rise in Requests for Different School Seats After Brooklyn District's New Admission Lottery
summary: Appeals offer an early peek at how families are adjusting to city's efforts to better integrate nation's largest school district. In the wake of a new admissions lottery to boost diversity, more families in Brooklyn's District 15 asked for a change in their middle-school assignments for the fall.

title: U.S. Cities Prepare for Federal Immigration Raids
summary: Los Angeles, Chicago and Miami are among the cities expecting deportation enforcement operations to begin Sunday. Several U.S. cities are preparing for federal immigration raids beginning Sunday morning as President Trump looked to follow through on plans to move enforcement actions beyond the southern border.

title: Marijuana Ties Are Hurting More Filers in Bankruptcy Courts
summary: Justice Department steps up enforcement actions as marijuana use and distribution remain illegal at the federal level. A little-known division of the Justice Department is using the nation's bankruptcy courts to impose the federal marijuana ban in states that have legalized pot, preventing people who work in the cannabis industry from using the bankruptcy system to save their home or business.

title: It's Not Too Late for Bayer to Heal
summary: Legal liabilities from the Monsanto deal have hammered Bayer shares, but the situation is likely to improve.

title: Bitcoin Is Back Above $10,000 and Investors Say This Rally Is Different
summary: The world's most popular cryptocurrency gets a boost from Facebook's plan to launch Libra. Bitcoin rose over $10,000 for the first time in over a year, riding a new wave of optimism about the value and future of digital currencies.

title: Hoboken Takes E-Scooters for a Spin, and Complaints Follow
summary: In the first 24 hours of launch of pilot program in the city, local police received more than 1,500 complaints and comments. In the first 24 hours of the launch of an electric-scooter pilot program in the city of Hoboken, N.J., the local police department received more than 1,500 complaints and comments about the scooters, its police chief said.

title: Bulldozing a Modernist Landmark
summary: The looming demolition of Frank Lloyd Wright's Booth cottage is the latest example in a long history of our culture's disregard for its architectural past..

title: Global Central Bank Shift Eases Drag on Chinese Currency
summary: The offshore yuan has gained 1% from its 2019 lows after signs the Federal Reserve could lower interest rates later this year. Shifts toward easier monetary policy by central banks in the U.S. and Europe have reduced some of the downward pressure building on China's currency.

title: In Khashoggi Murder Trial, Absence of Crown Prince Aide Stands Out
summary: U.S. and U.N. have criticized Saudi Arabia's trial of those charged in the journalist's killing for being secretive and too slow. In a Riyadh courtroom, prosecutors have outlined evidence implicating a top lieutenant of Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman in the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, according to Saudi officials not authorized to speak publicly.

title: Debate Veterans' Advice for a Crowded Stage: Be Brief and Ready for Broken Rules
summary: Candidates and aides from the packed 2016 Republican field say they learned lessons the 2020 Democratic contenders should heed. Have one good line ready that could go viral. Don't count on getting much speaking time, unless you are Joe Biden. And don't expect your fellow participants to stick to the rules.

title: Plastic Bans: What You Need to Know
summary: Single-use plastics have become a focal point for lawmakers seeking to reduce waste, but the industry is pushing back. Cities and states across the U.S. have been enacting a flurry of restrictions on single-use plastics.

title: How to Spot (and Avoid) Fake Google Maps Listings
summary: Misleading information on Google Maps can lead you astray; an urgent-care center that doesn't exist. Caroline Ige of Silver Spring, Md., woke up recently in the middle of the night with sharp pain in her lower abdomen.

title: Hong Kong Protesters Disband After Besieging Police Headquarters
summary: Demonstrators want controversial extradition bill to be fully withdrawn and call for resignation of Chief Executive Lam. HONG KONG-Thousands of protesters besieged the city's police headquarters on Friday, extending a political crisis in the city sparked by a proposed extradition law that the government has since put a stop to in an effort to ease unrest.

title: Women's World Cup TV Viewership Is on a Record Pace
summary: 750 million people watched the tournament in 2015; FIFA estimates that nearly 1 billion could tune in this summer. The Women's World Cup is just past the halfway mark and already it is on pace to break several viewership records, both in the U.S. and across the globe. 750 million people watched the tournament in 2015; FIFA estimates that nearly 1 billion could tune in this summer.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Building the Wind Turbines Was Easy. The Hard Part Was Plugging Them In.
summary: In the Oklahoma panhandle, one entrepreneur saw a future fueled by cheap and clean energy. But there was a big snag.. Adapted from "SUPERPOWER: One Man's Quest to Transform American Energy" by Wall Street Journal reporter Russell Gold, to be published by Simon & Schuster, Inc., on June 25.

title: For Ponzi Victims, the Aftermath Is Long
summary: When scams collapse, professionals sweep in to help the recovery; the first checks to investors can take almost a decade. In 2008, authorities exposed Minnesota businessman Thomas Petters as running one of the largest Ponzi schemes in U.S. history. A decade later, efforts to repay at least some of the $1.9 billion that investors claimed they lost are still under way.

title: Missouri Health Agency Lets License Lapse for State's Last Abortion Clinic
summary: Clinic will continue providing abortion services while court injunction remains in effect. Missouri's health department declined to renew the license of the state's last abortion clinic Friday, in a move that could eventually make the state the first in the U.S. without an abortion clinic in decades.

title: Stocks Are Sitting Pretty Heading Into Summer
summary: S&P 500 is heading toward its best June since 1955; Dow Jones Industrial Average is on pace for its best June since 1938. U.S. stocks notched a banner week after the Federal Reserve signaled it could cut short-term rates in the months ahead, putting stocks on pace for their best June in more than a half-century.
